Message.Title: Future Scenario
Message.Msg: A chess game is now in effect. Dell made the first move w/ a lowball offer. Southeastern and other shareholders have countered, pledging to use all their resources to block deal. M. Dell might threaten to walk but it's bull, as he stands to make huge money even at higher offer. Dell, Silverlake and MSFT are very hot for this deal and foresee very nice gains. Dell has stated as much in public that he foresees substantial growth as they focus on enterprise and data center markets. He cannot really bluff too hard or for too long because there is some urgency to get deal done and focus on new direction. The share price might drop a bit from here on the Dell bluff. M. Dell and Silverlake will then make a higher offer, probably in the 16-17 range, giving Southeastern an out at their cost basis. Shareholders accept new offer. I expect the new offer comes in before April or not long after the go shop period ends and vote for shareholder approval will come sometime mid-April.

Message.Title: When is vote?
Message.Msg: When is exact date of vote? Are any members of board up for vote? Who are the board members? What companies do they work for? How do they profit from stealing our company from us? What about acting in good faith? I bet as Michael Dell was diversifing his investments and selling his dell shares to invest in other companies, he has net worth of roughly $25 billion dollars. That is more than current net worth of Dell. I would like to know who is shorting Dell stock. Has Michael Dell ever shorted Dell stock? Has Silver Lake or Microsoft ? How about people who work for them?If the deal doesnt go through, are they planning to short? Is this data published? Can we get list of people and who shorts? Or are they all corporate entities outside this country like in Grand Cayman Islands where you cant get answers. Transparency is very important. We dont have it.

Topic.Title: the filing is right there on bloomberg..Vanguard just bought 7 million more Dell bonds..they own the most

Message.Msg: Remember...these are huge pools of money. They have to buy SOMETHING. They are very well diversified (i.e. the Dell bonds are probably just a tiny percentage of the overall portfolio). Adding Dell bonds for a higher yield and nice potential gain if deal falls apart is a good bet. If the deal goes through, the odds are good that the bonds will be repaid in full on maturity. Definitely something a bond fund manager looks for.

Topic.Title: Got the F out at 13.67

Message.Msg: No not lying at all. Looked at my tax lots and confirmed the purchase date. Trying to make a point that its no point holding on to Dell anymore. If the deal goes through you get 13.65 and if it doesn't the share price could drop to single digits. Southeastern does not have enough weight to stop the deal and the Cheapster Michael Dell would not pay a dime above the offer he presented. HP has its own issues and can't step up to buy out Dell at this time. There are no other option left. It's practically checkmate for the shareholders. Well, I pulled the trigger and got out. Just disappointed that I could only make 5 bucks a share after parking the money in Dell for 4 long years. Good luck to you.
